elements.content: An interesting coordination complex based on a designed X ligand has been prepared. It displays a novel 4-connected uninodal net with point symbol (42·63·8) and vertex symbol [4.6.4.6.6.1012] which has never been observed in metal−organic frameworks/coordination polymers. Meanwhile, the compound displays intriguing structural features of interpenetration and self-catenation, as well as nonlinear optical properties.
elements.clean_text: An interesting coordination complex based on a designed X ligand has been prepared. It displays a novel 4-connected uninodal net with point symbol (42⋅63⋅8) and vertex symbol [4.6.4.6.6.1012] which has never been observed in metal-organic frameworks/coordination polymers. Meanwhile, the compound displays intriguing structural features of interpenetration and self-catenation, as well as nonlinear optical properties.

elements.content: Metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) and coordination polymers (CPs) have attracted much research attention due to their promising applications in gas storage and separation, catalysis, magnetism, and second-order nonlinear optical (NLO) properties. Likewise, topology focuses on the structural complexity, variety, and relativity reflected by CPs, which is greatly favored through the use of mathematic methods. Some nets often occur in nature, whereas other nets have never been found (among these, dia, pcu, and srs appear among the highest frequencies). It is not unusual that networks with high symmetry are more likely to appear in nature. Moreover, new nets (subnet) can also be derived from a given net (supernet) through node correspondences and a sequence of transformations; as result a large collection of derived uninodal and binodal nets has been produced and now can be used to compare to real structures.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) and coordination polymers (CPs) have attracted much research attention due to their promising applications in gas storage and separation, catalysis, magnetism, and second-order nonlinear optical (NLO) properties. Likewise, topology focuses on the structural complexity, variety, and relativity reflected by CPs, which is greatly favored through the use of mathematic methods. Some nets often occur in nature, whereas other nets have never been found (among these, dia, pcu, and srs appear among the highest frequencies). It is not unusual that networks with high symmetry are more likely to appear in nature. Moreover, new nets (subnet) can also be derived from a given net (supernet) through node correspondences and a sequence of transformations; as result a large collection of derived uninodal and binodal nets has been produced and now can be used to compare to real structures.

elements.content: It is no doubt that the discovery of artificial MOFs with predicted subnet topologies is of great significance in understanding supernet−subnet relations based on the knowledge of the chemical properties of the components (metals and ligands). Therefore, tiny variation of nodes may generate huge differences on topologies since the network topology is reflected by the symmetry of nodes and nature of edges.
elements.clean_text: It is no doubt that the discovery of artificial MOFs with predicted subnet topologies is of great significance in understanding supernet-subnet relations based on the knowledge of the chemical properties of the components (metals and ligands). Therefore, tiny variation of nodes may generate huge differences on topologies since the network topology is reflected by the symmetry of nodes and nature of edges.

elements.content: Herein, we report a zinc MOF [Zn2(X)(H2O)]2·H2O (1) (H4X = tetrakis[4-(carboxyphenyl)oxamethyl] methane acid), which displays intriguing structural features of interpenetration and self-catenation, as well as NLO properties. X-ray analysis of the structure reveals two crystallographically independent Zn atoms, one X ligand, one aqua ligand, and a half uncoordinated water molecule (Figure a, top-left). Both of the Zn atoms display tetrahedral coordination geometries: one coordinated by four carboxylate O atoms and the other by three carboxylate and water O atoms. The two Zn atoms are held together by three bis-bidentate carboxylate groups, forming a triple lamella “paddle-wheel” secondary building unit (SBU) (Figure a, top-right), and the remaining position of each tetrahedra is occupied by either a unidentate carboxylate oxygen or a coordinated water molecule. Accordingly, three carboxylate groups of an X ligand are bis-bidentate and the other one is unidentate. It should be noted the triple lamella is an uncommon SBU based on a dinuclear unit. Cross-linking of the SBUs through X ligands generates a very complicated three-dimensional (3D) network (Figure b). Calculations using PLATON indicate that complex 1 has a solvent accessible volume of 2277.4 Å3 (15.9%) after the removal of uncoordinated water molecules. Experiments with pure gas on 1 at low pressure (1 bar) revealed that it has no uptake of nitrogen.
elements.clean_text: Herein, we report a zinc MOF [Zn2(X)(H2O)]2⋅H2O (1) (H4X = tetrakis[4-(carboxyphenyl)oxamethyl] methane acid), which displays intriguing structural features of interpenetration and self-catenation, as well as NLO properties. X-ray analysis of the structure reveals two crystallographically independent Zn atoms, one X ligand, one aqua ligand, and a half uncoordinated water molecule (Figure a, top-left). Both of the Zn atoms display tetrahedral coordination geometries: one coordinated by four carboxylate O atoms and the other by three carboxylate and water O atoms. The two Zn atoms are held together by three bis-bidentate carboxylate groups, forming a triple lamella "paddle-wheel" secondary building unit (SBU) (Figure a, top-right), and the remaining position of each tetrahedra is occupied by either a unidentate carboxylate oxygen or a coordinated water molecule. Accordingly, three carboxylate groups of an X ligand are bis-bidentate and the other one is unidentate. It should be noted the triple lamella is an uncommon SBU based on a dinuclear unit. Cross-linking of the SBUs through X ligands generates a very complicated three-dimensional (3D) network (Figure b). Calculations using PLATON  indicate that complex 1 has a solvent accessible volume of 2277.4 Å3 (15.9%) after the removal of uncoordinated water molecules. Experiments with pure gas on 1 at low pressure (1 bar) revealed that it has no uptake of nitrogen.

elements.content: Topological simplification using TOPOS software indicates a novel 4-connected uninodal net with point symbol (42·63·8) and vertex symbol [4.6.4.6.6.1012] by considering X ligands (Figure a, bottom-left) and dinuclear paddle-wheel SBUs (Figure a, bottom-right) as nodes. This net was derived in analyzing supernet−subnet relations by TOPOS as subnet of the 6-connected (48·67)-sxa, and has never been observed in MOFs/CPs.
elements.clean_text: Topological simplification using TOPOS software indicates a novel 4-connected uninodal net with point symbol (42⋅63⋅8) and vertex symbol [4.6.4.6.6.1012] by considering X ligands (Figure a, bottom-left) and dinuclear paddle-wheel SBUs (Figure a, bottom-right) as nodes. This net was derived in analyzing supernet-subnet relations by TOPOS as subnet of the 6-connected (48⋅67)-sxa, and has never been observed in MOFs/CPs.

elements.content: (a) X-ray structure of the basic unit of complex 1 (top-left, uncoordinated water molecules are omitted for clarity), dinuclear SBU (top-right), connectivity of the ligand (bottom-left) and SBU (bottom-right); (b) the evolution pattern from a SBU.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) X-ray structure of the basic unit of complex 1 (top-left, uncoordinated water molecules are omitted for clarity), dinuclear SBU (top-right), connectivity of the ligand (bottom-left) and SBU (bottom-right); (b) the evolution pattern from a SBU.

elements.content: The new 4-connected (42·63·8) net is also self-catenated as shown by the 6-membered circuits as highlighted in Figure a. Moreover, the overall framework shows 2-fold interpenetration of class IIa, with the two nets related by a 2-fold axis down the crystallographic axis c (Figure b).
elements.clean_text: The new 4-connected (42⋅63⋅8) net is also self-catenated as shown by the 6-membered circuits as highlighted in Figure a. Moreover, the overall framework shows 2-fold interpenetration of class IIa, with the two nets related by a 2-fold axis down the crystallographic axis c (Figure b).

elements.content: Our previous study using the same metal ion and ligand resulted in the MOF [Zn2(X)(CH3CH2OH)]·3H2O (2) containing zinc-oxide chains. Examination of the topology of 2 gives a new non -interpenetrated binodal 4,6-connected net with point symbol (66)(614·7). In order to understand the possible relation between the two complexes, a pair of equivalent edges of the 6-connected node of net 2 was removed. The derived net is the most frequently observed dia topology, but now 3-fold interpenetrated as shown in (the removal of any other two edges of the 6-connected node reduce the structure into 2D layers). This is particularly significant because, as described earlier, a dia net is most likely to form based on the tetrahedral metal centers and tetrahedral ligands.
elements.clean_text: Our previous study using the same metal ion and ligand resulted in the MOF [Zn2(X)(CH3CH2OH)]⋅3H2O (2) containing zinc-oxide chains. Examination of the topology of 2 gives a new non -interpenetrated binodal 4,6-connected net with point symbol (66)(614⋅7). In order to understand the possible relation between the two complexes, a pair of equivalent edges of the 6-connected node of net 2 was removed. The derived net is the most frequently observed dia topology, but now 3-fold interpenetrated as shown in  (the removal of any other two edges of the 6-connected node reduce the structure into 2D layers). This is particularly significant because, as described earlier, a dia net is most likely to form based on the tetrahedral metal centers and tetrahedral ligands.

elements.content: (a) Topological presentation the 3D net showing the self-catenation pattern; (b) a presentation of the 2-fold interpenetration in complex 1.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Topological presentation the 3D net showing the self-catenation pattern; (b) a presentation of the 2-fold interpenetration in complex 1.

elements.content: Complex 1 crystallizes in the acentric space group Fdd2 (No. 43), which prompts us to investigate its second-order NLO property. The second-harmonic generation (SHG) measurements on the sieved powder samples (70−100 mesh), using 1064 nm radiation, revealed that complex 1 exhibits a SHG response about 1.5 times that of technologically useful potassium dihydrogen phosphate (KDP). The X-ray powder diffraction patterns of 1 after being heated to 140 and 300 °C reveal that its structural integrity can persist far beyond the loss of water molecules (). The UV absorption spectrum reveals complex 1 is almost totally transparent in the visible region (). The optical diffuse reflectance spectrum indicates a large optical band gap of 4.1 eV (). Moreover, complex 1 is insoluble in common solvents as a result of its polymeric structure. On the basis of these arguments, it is concluded that complex 1 is potentially a new candidate for second-order NLO materials.
elements.clean_text: Complex 1 crystallizes in the acentric space group Fdd2 (No. 43), which prompts us to investigate its second-order NLO property. The second-harmonic generation (SHG) measurements on the sieved powder samples (70-100 mesh), using 1064 nm radiation, revealed that complex 1 exhibits a SHG response about 1.5 times that of technologically useful potassium dihydrogen phosphate (KDP). The X-ray powder diffraction patterns of 1 after being heated to 140 and 300 °C reveal that its structural integrity can persist far beyond the loss of water molecules (). The UV absorption spectrum reveals complex 1 is almost totally transparent in the visible region (). The optical diffuse reflectance spectrum indicates a large optical band gap of 4.1 eV (). Moreover, complex 1 is insoluble in common solvents as a result of its polymeric structure. On the basis of these arguments, it is concluded that complex 1 is potentially a new candidate for second-order NLO materials.

elements.content: To obtain molecular materials displaying significant second-order NLO effects, it is necessary to have electric dipoles in non-centrosymmetric compounds. With this point of view, various donor−acceptor substituted conjugated systems have been widely used to synthesize SHG CPs. However, there have been relative few examples of synthesizing NLO CPs from symmetric ligands. Derived from the achiral X ligand and Zn(II) ions, compounds 1 and 2 crystallize both in noncentrosymmetric space groups. However, employing the same ligand and metal center, Thallapally, Atwood, and co-workers obtained three compounds (3-fold pts [Zn2(X)(H2O)(DMF)]·3DMF, 2-fold dia [Zn2(X)(DMF)]·x(H2O,DMF), and 2-fold lon [Zn(H2X)]·x(H2O,DMF)) which show potential for gas separation but crystallize in centrosymmetric space groups. Their work helps to gain insight into our non-centrosymmetic solids. In our opinion, the metal−ligand coordination bonds present a unique opportunity for the construction of noncentric solids from symmetric ligands. The coordination geometries of metal ions have a profound effect on the topology of network and finally induce the compound packing in a centro- or noncentrosymmetric space group. It has been shown that an even number of interpenetrated dia nets often leads to inversion centers present in the network, while an odd-number of interpenetrated dia nets will be more likely non-centrosymmetric. Indeed, the 2-fold dia net reported is centrosymmetric, while compound 2 related to 3-fold dia is noncentric. As for compound 1, the space group Fdd2 gives non-centrosymmetric packing. Inspection of the structure of compound 1 shows that two kinds of 2-fold helices can be found along the b axis. The helices are related by a d-glide plane (parallel to the ab plane and represented as lavender in Figure ), so they are left-handed and right-handed. Meanwhile, because of the d-glide reflection, all the building blocks (tipple paddle-wheel and organic moiety) link as a head-to-tail arrangement which ensures alignment of the dipoles along the helices.
elements.clean_text: To obtain molecular materials displaying significant second-order NLO effects, it is necessary to have electric dipoles in non-centrosymmetric compounds. With this point of view, various donor-acceptor substituted conjugated systems have been widely used to synthesize SHG CPs. However, there have been relative few examples of synthesizing NLO CPs from symmetric ligands. Derived from the achiral X ligand and Zn(II) ions, compounds 1 and 2 crystallize both in noncentrosymmetric space groups. However, employing the same ligand and metal center, Thallapally, Atwood, and co-workers obtained three compounds (3-fold pts [Zn2(X)(H2O)(DMF)]⋅3DMF, 2-fold dia [Zn2(X)(DMF)]⋅x(H2O,DMF), and 2-fold lon [Zn(H2X)]⋅x(H2O,DMF)) which show potential for gas separation but crystallize in centrosymmetric space groups. Their work helps to gain insight into our non-centrosymmetic solids. In our opinion, the metal-ligand coordination bonds present a unique opportunity for the construction of noncentric solids from symmetric ligands. The coordination geometries of metal ions have a profound effect on the topology of network and finally induce the compound packing in a centro- or noncentrosymmetric space group. It has been shown that an even number of interpenetrated dia nets often leads to inversion centers present in the network, while an odd-number of interpenetrated dia nets will be more likely non-centrosymmetric. Indeed, the 2-fold dia net reported is centrosymmetric, while compound 2 related to 3-fold dia is noncentric. As for compound 1, the space group Fdd2 gives non-centrosymmetric packing. Inspection of the structure of compound 1 shows that two kinds of 2-fold helices can be found along the b axis. The helices are related by a d-glide plane (parallel to the ab plane and represented as lavender in Figure ), so they are left-handed and right-handed. Meanwhile, because of the d-glide reflection, all the building blocks (tipple paddle-wheel and organic moiety) link as a head-to-tail arrangement which ensures alignment of the dipoles along the helices.

elements.content: The left-handed (aqua) and right-handed (pink) 21 helix related by d-glide (lavender) and diagram showing compound 1 along [001].
elements.clean_text: 3  The left-handed (aqua) and right-handed (pink) 21 helix related by d-glide (lavender) and diagram showing compound 1 along [001].

elements.content: In summary, an interesting coordination complex 1 based on a designed X ligand has been prepared, which features interesting network interpenetration, self-catenation, and NLO properties. Our analysis revealed that although the basic dinuclear SBUs and X ligands are tetrahedral nodes, complex 1 possesses a new topology different from the dia topology shown by another analogue complex 2 reported previously by our group. It is believed that subtle differences in coordination geometries of metal centers may result in extremely different topological nets and provide a way to achieve the tunability of properties. This result inspires us to explore topological studies on coordination complexes to rationally design functional materials.
elements.clean_text: In summary, an interesting coordination complex 1 based on a designed X ligand has been prepared, which features interesting network interpenetration, self-catenation, and NLO properties. Our analysis revealed that although the basic dinuclear SBUs and X ligands are tetrahedral nodes, complex 1 possesses a new topology different from the dia topology shown by another analogue complex 2 reported previously by our group. It is believed that subtle differences in coordination geometries of metal centers may result in extremely different topological nets and provide a way to achieve the tunability of properties. This result inspires us to explore topological studies on coordination complexes to rationally design functional materials.

elements.content: Synthesis and general characterization (EA, TGA, and PXRD), crystallographic data in CIF format, and additional structural figures are given as a PDF file. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

elements.content: Crystal data for [Zn2(X)(H2O)]2·H2O, Orthorhombic, Fdd2, M r = 1540.52, a = 19.891(3) Å, b = 24.552(5) Å, c = 29.286(6) Å, V = 14302(5) Å3, Z = 8, D calcd = 1.431 Mg·m−3. The final least-squares refinements converged at R 1 (wR 2) = 0.08381/0.2245 and S = 1.011 for 6025 reflections with I > 2σ(I). More details about the crystallographic studies are given in the .

metadata.title: New Metal−Organic Framework with Uninodal 4-Connected Topology Displaying Interpenetration, Self-Catenation, and Second-Order Nonlinear Optical Response
